awd_titl_txt: Investigation of User-Interface and Human-Robot Performance for Supernumerary Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Supernumerary robots are assistive devices that may attach to the human body and be controlled to perform coordinated actions with a person's natural limbs. Supernumerary robots have potential to reduce risk and increase human capability in physically-demanding and/or dangerous workplace activities, including construction, agricultural applications, search-and-rescue, and outer space exploration. The research objective of this project is to advance a fundamental understanding of human-machine interaction within the context of real-time dexterous control of a "third arm" supernumerary robot. The project will develop a novel human-machine interface that will allow a human to use electromyographic activity (EMG) to command the robot in a closed-loop manner using multimodal sensory feedback derived from visual and supplemental vibrotactile information. The project team will use the new system in two sets of human subject experiments designed to explore the bi-directional adaptation that occurs within the human-robot dyad as the human learns to control the machine in a novel three-handed manipulation task, even as the robotic controller adapts to the changing signal properties of muscle EMGs as the human user fatigues. The project advances the National Science Foundation's mission to promote the progress of science, to advance national health, prosperity, and welfare, by advancing a fundamental understanding of co-adaptive human-machine partnerships. Broader impacts of this project include establishing a summer program for elementary and middle school female students to introduce principles of robotics, sensors, neuroscience, and human performance. The summer program is directly aligned with the National Science Foundation's goal to support activities designed to increase the participation of women and other underrepresented groups in science and technology.

This project explores human-machine cooperation within the context of a "third arm" supernumerary robot. Two sets of human subject experiments are planned.  The first establishes the feasibility of a novel, adaptive, EMG-based methodology for haptic-guided closed-loop control of a supernumerary robotic arm's end-effector. Several biosignals sensitive to cognitive state will be recorded, including pupillometry, galvanic skin response, heart rate variability, and electroencephalography (EEG). Subjects will perform a point-to-point trajectory task and a 3D version of the Fitts's Law task to assess control efficiency with and without vibrotactile performance feedback applied to the user's foot. The second explores the coupled dynamics of short-term human learning of a three-handed manipulation task that requires the user to coordinate motions of their two hands with those of the supernumerary robot to manipulate a novel three-element object to recreate specific desired poses. At the same time, online computational learning adaptations of the robot's grip force will be driven by perturbations of object kinematics and kinetics caused by the user's natural arms. The work will advance a fundamental understanding of (1) human interface performance in physical workspaces where cognition is embodied in both the human and supernumerary robot; (2) cognitive load and neuroplasticity using EEG and other physiological measurements; and (3) improvements in tri-manual coordination and manipulation capability arising from short-term training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supernumerary robots are assistive devices that may attach to the human body (or be in proximity to a human operator) and be controlled to perform coordinated actions with a person's natural limbs. Supernumerary robots have potential to reduce risk and increase human capability in physically-demanding and/or dangerous workplace activities, including construction, agricultural applications, search-and-rescue, and outer space exploration. The research objective of this project was to advance a fundamental understanding of human-machine interaction within the context of a "third arm" supernumerary robot.

Research Outcomes: During the course of this project, we 1) established multiple hardware and software testbeds to support the goals of the project, 2) studied trimanual control within a multidisciplinary framework using the testbeds we developed, and 3) established a summer learning experience for middle school students incorporating robotics and neuroscience.

One of the main challenges for using supernumerary robots in complex dexterous tasks is that the robot must be controlled by the human, while the human is using their natural limbs to simultaneously perform another part of the task. Therefore, the supernumerary robot must be controlled without using the hands/arms of the human. Furthermore, the human must coordinate the use of their two arms/hands with each other (called bimanual control in neuroscience) and additionally with a robot at the same time (called trimanual or multilimb control).

We constructed many experiments that included robots, haptics, and various forms of visual feedback.  For example, in some experiments the subjects needed to use two joysticks to control the x and y directions of a computer cursor, while at the same time using leg electrical signals to control the z (depth) direction of a computer cursor. In other experiments, instead of a leg electrical signal, we used a foot-pedal.  In some experiments, subjects viewed the location of the cursor while it was moving (visual feedback), while also feeling where the cursor was going using vibration on the skin (haptic feedback). In some experiments, the leg controlled an external UR5E robotic arm. During Covid, we were able to study some aspects of motor-control using the track-pad on laptop computers controlled by subjects from home.

The major findings were that humans are capable of using three limbs in coordination when performing tasks with various human-machine interfaces, and many people can get quite good at using three limbs in coordination. We found that the details of the human-machine interface and the types of feedback matter, specifically in terms of how well people can perform the task after training, how fast they can improve during training, and exactly how they do the task in fine-details. Please see our published papers for more technical details of our research results. Additional papers are forthcoming. It is our hope that these results help other researchers in developing useful multi-limb controllers for supernumerary robots and other applications.

Unfortunately, the Covid pandemic hit very shortly after we were awarded this grant, shutting down all labs for an extended period and stopping all in-person human subject experiments.  As a result, we shifted some of our originally planned experiments to other relevant experiments that fit within the scope of this grant.

Broader Impact Outcomes: After the Covid shutdown was lifted, we established the UCD Mind and Machine Summer Camp. We ran the camp for three summers, in conjunction with the City of Woodland, California (two summers) and the Davis, California Unified School District (one summer). The camp was offered in a 3-day format and was developed for middle-school aged children. Day 1 of camp focused on introducing students to the brain, input-output, and programming using Python to control an educational microcontroller board (Parallax Corporation micro:bits). Day 2 was spent on the UC Davis campus visiting project labs and other campus facilities, and viewing demonstrations from graduate students and faculty/researchers. Over the years, some highlights of the demonstrations included how to use an EEG cap to record brain waves to control a computer game, and speaking to a remote college student using a tele-presence robot. Day 3, the campers finished learning the basics of programming while also discussing how people learn from a neuroscience perspective. Finally, all the students participated in a final robot maze-challenge. Students at the end of Day 3 were each awarded a certificate and named Robotics Ambassadors.
